articles.headline: Fear of Deflation Lurks as Global Demand Drops
articles.snippet: Consumer cutbacks could lead to falling prices, suffocating investment and worsening joblessness for months.
articles.abstract: Consumer cutbacks could lead to falling prices, suffocating investment and worsening joblessness for months.
articles.lead_paragraph: As dozens of countries slip deeper into financial distress, a new threat may be gathering force within the American economy  the prospect that goods will pile up waiting for buyers and prices will fall, suffocating fresh investment and worsening joblessness for months or even years.

articles.headline: A Rescue Hindered by Politics
articles.snippet: There are serious, smart plans to help struggling homeowners. And yet one plan is still missing. Where, oh, where is the government’s plan?
articles.abstract: There are serious, smart plans to help struggling homeowners. And yet one plan is still missing. Where, oh, where is the government’s plan?
articles.lead_paragraph: Plans. Have I ever been inundated with plans. Deluged with them, actually.

articles.headline: Budgets Squeezed, Some Families Bypass Organics
articles.snippet: The organic industry is starting to show signs that a decade-long sales boom may be coming to an end.
articles.abstract: The organic industry is starting to show signs that a decade-long sales boom may be coming to an end.
articles.lead_paragraph: Once upon a time, sales of organic and natural products were growing in double digits most years. Enthusiastic grocers and venture capitalists prowled the halls of trade shows looking for the next big thing. Grass-fed beef? Organic baby food? Gluten-free energy bars?

articles.headline: Banks Alter Loan Terms to Head Off Foreclosures
articles.snippet: JPMorgan Chase became the latest big bank to pledge to cut monthly payments, by lowering interest rates and temporarily reducing loan balances.
articles.abstract: JPMorgan Chase became the latest big bank to pledge to cut monthly payments, by lowering interest rates and temporarily reducing loan balances.
articles.lead_paragraph: Even as political pressure builds in Washington for a sweeping program to help struggling homeowners, some banks are realizing that it may be good business to keep borrowers in their homes.
articles.byline: By Vikas Bajaj and Eric Dash

articles.headline: A Monthlong Walk on the Wildest Side of the Stock Market
articles.snippet: The wildest month in the history of Wall Street ended on Halloween with both scary and thrilling price movements.
articles.abstract: The wildest month in the history of Wall Street ended on Halloween with both scary and thrilling price movements.
articles.lead_paragraph: The wildest month in the history of Wall Street ended on Halloween with both scary and thrilling price movements.

articles.headline: Hopefuls Differ as They Reject Gay Marriage
articles.snippet: Religion guides Barack Obama’s opposition; John McCain is influenced by generational and cultural experiences.
articles.abstract: Religion guides Barack Obama’s opposition; John McCain is influenced by generational and cultural experiences.
articles.lead_paragraph: Several gay friends and wealthy gay donors to Senator Barack Obama have asked him over the years why, as a matter of logic and fairness, he opposes same-sex marriage even though he has condemned old miscegenation laws that would have barred his black father from marrying his white mother.

articles.headline: A Warning, a Blast, a Fight to Save an Afghan Life
articles.snippet: In an isolated Afghan outpost, it was up to an American Army doctor and medics to keep a wounded Afghan alive.
articles.abstract: In an isolated Afghan outpost, it was up to an American Army doctor and medics to keep a wounded Afghan alive.
articles.lead_paragraph: COMBAT OUTPOST LOWELL, Afghanistan  Jamaludin, an aging Afghan cook, twisted and writhed on the green stretcher. Blood ran from his mouth and nose. Medics had cut away his clothes, revealing puncture holes where shrapnel from a Taliban mortar round had struck him minutes before.

articles.headline: A Splash of Green for the Rust Belt
articles.snippet: With unemployment up, renewable energy has become a crucial source of good jobs for laid-off Rust Belt workers.
articles.abstract: With unemployment up, renewable energy has become a crucial source of good jobs for laid-off Rust Belt workers.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEWTON, Iowa

articles.headline: Was There a Loan It Didn’t Like?
articles.snippet: A shareholder complaint depicts WaMu’s mortgage lending operation as a boiler room where volume was paramount and questionable loans were pushed through for profit.
articles.abstract: A shareholder complaint depicts WaMu’s mortgage lending operation as a boiler room where volume was paramount and questionable loans were pushed through for profit.
articles.lead_paragraph: AS a senior mortgage underwriter, Keysha Cooper was proud of her ability to spot fraud and other problems in a loan application. A decade of vetting mortgage documents had taught her plenty, she says.

articles.headline: As Taliban Overwhelm Police, Pakistanis Hit Back
articles.snippet: Citizens have been encouraged to form posses of their own in a sign of the shortcomings of Pakistan’s police forces.
articles.abstract: Citizens have been encouraged to form posses of their own in a sign of the shortcomings of Pakistan’s police forces.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHALBANDI, Pakistan — On a rainy Friday evening in early August, six Taliban fighters attacked a police post in a village in Buner, a quiet farming valley just outside Pakistan’s lawless tribal region.
articles.byline: By Jane Perlez and Pir Zubair Shah

articles.headline: Candidates Make Their Final Push on Reshaped Map
articles.snippet: Barack Obama is campaigning in states that went Republican four years ago, while John McCain is pushing back with a new burst of advertising.
articles.abstract: Barack Obama is campaigning in states that went Republican four years ago, while John McCain is pushing back with a new burst of advertising.
articles.lead_paragraph: Senators John McCain and Barack Obama began their final push for the White House on Saturday across an electoral map markedly different from four years ago, evidence of Mr. Obama’s success at putting new states into contention and limiting Mr. McCain’s options in the final hours.

articles.headline: Obama-Inspired Black Voters Warm to Politics
articles.snippet: Many blacks who have been disaffected, apolitical, discouraged or just bored with politics have snapped to attention this year.
articles.abstract: Many blacks who have been disaffected, apolitical, discouraged or just bored with politics have snapped to attention this year.
articles.lead_paragraph: Growing up in St. Louis in the 1950s and ’60s, Deddrick Battle came to believe that the political process was not for people like him — a struggling black man whose vote, he was convinced, surely would not count for much of anything. The thought became ingrained as an adult, almost like common sense.

articles.headline: From Midwest to M.T.A., Pain From Global Gamble
articles.snippet: Wisconsin schools and New York subways are among the players in a financial fiasco that has ricocheted globally.
articles.abstract: Wisconsin schools and New York subways are among the players in a financial fiasco that has ricocheted globally.
articles.lead_paragraph: “People come up to me in the grocery store and say, ‘How did we get suckered into this?’ ”
articles.byline: By Charles Duhigg and Carter Dougherty

articles.headline: Lighting Up the Night, and a Legal Battle
articles.snippet: A lawsuit against ATK Thiokol over military flares may raise questions about the reliability of military contractors and the safety of their products.
articles.abstract: A lawsuit against ATK Thiokol over military flares may raise questions about the reliability of military contractors and the safety of their products.
articles.lead_paragraph: North Ogden, Utah

articles.headline: Sheepish, Proud or Set to Flip a Coin, They’re Still Undecided
articles.snippet: Some are still wrestling with the question of how to vote. Which raises a follow-up: What is up with these people?
articles.abstract: Some are still wrestling with the question of how to vote. Which raises a follow-up: What is up with these people?
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Senators Barack Obama and John McCain have stood (or sat) for 36 debates, endured thousands of interviews, and spent hundreds of millions of dollars on advertisements and the better part of two years trying to convince voters that they are worthy of the presidency, or at least a vote.

articles.headline: U.S. Rejects G.M.’s Call for Help in a Merger
articles.snippet: Officials were said to be reluctant to broaden the $700 billion rescue program to include industrial companies.
articles.abstract: Officials were said to be reluctant to broaden the $700 billion rescue program to include industrial companies.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  The Treasury Department has turned down a request by General Motors for up to $10 billion to help finance the automaker’s possible merger with Chrysler, according to people close to the discussions.
articles.byline: By Bill Vlasic and Micheline Maynard

articles.headline: Elections Are Fertile Ground for Testing Market Soothsayers
articles.snippet: There is a long tradition of market watchers seeking connections between two of America’s favorite pastimes: picking presidents and picking stocks.
articles.abstract: There is a long tradition of market watchers seeking connections between two of America’s favorite pastimes: picking presidents and picking stocks.
articles.lead_paragraph: In 1967, after several years of research, a young market forecaster named Yale Hirsch unveiled a grand theory of the relationship between presidential elections and the stock market.

articles.headline: Campaigns in a Web 2.0 World
articles.snippet: Not since John F. Kennedy’s win in 1960 has changing technology had such an impact on the political campaigns and the organizations covering them.
articles.abstract: Not since John F. Kennedy’s win in 1960 has changing technology had such an impact on the political campaigns and the organizations covering them.
articles.lead_paragraph: Shortly after 9 a.m. on Oct. 19, Colin Powell endorsed Barack Obama for president during the taping of “Meet the Press” on NBC. Within minutes, the video was on the Web.
articles.byline: By David Carr and Brian Stelter

articles.headline: Young Viewers Flocking to CBS in a Season of Disappointments
articles.snippet: When did CBS, the network awash in cop shows featuring leading men in their 50s, become the hot network with young audiences?
articles.abstract: When did CBS, the network awash in cop shows featuring leading men in their 50s, become the hot network with young audiences?
articles.lead_paragraph: When did CBS, the network awash in cop shows featuring leading men in their 50s, become the hot network with young audiences?

articles.headline: Even Keel for Obama in Final Turn to Election
articles.snippet: Unflappable as he may be, Senator Barack Obama’s world is awash in powerful, conflicting emotions as the race nears its end.
articles.abstract: Unflappable as he may be, Senator Barack Obama’s world is awash in powerful, conflicting emotions as the race nears its end.
articles.lead_paragraph: SPRINGFIELD, Mo. — A cellphone was pressed to Senator Barack Obama’s ear as he slouched down in a black leather chair in the front cabin of his campaign airplane. He leaned away from the headrest, where his name is spelled out in blue stitching.

articles.headline: For McCain, Lighter End After Years on the Trail
articles.snippet: Senator John McCain’s aides say he is relieved that the race is almost over, and he appears just to be having a good time.
articles.abstract: Senator John McCain’s aides say he is relieved that the race is almost over, and he appears just to be having a good time.
articles.lead_paragraph: PETERBOROUGH, N.H. — Somewhere in a corner of northeastern Ohio, just five days before the presidential election that more than a few pundits have declared he will lose, Senator John McCain sat in the back of his campaign bus telling his favorite Henny Youngman jokes. No one laughed harder than he did.

articles.headline: The Struggles of a Game Maker Bog Down Viacom
articles.snippet: Sumner M. Redstone’s forced sale of more than $200 million in stock is the latest twist in a tumultuous decade for the Viacom chairman.
articles.abstract: Sumner M. Redstone’s forced sale of more than $200 million in stock is the latest twist in a tumultuous decade for the Viacom chairman.
articles.lead_paragraph: At 85, Sumner M. Redstone may be the world’s oldest video game addict.

articles.headline: Republicans Scrambling to Save Seats in Congress
articles.snippet: Republicans are trying to save embattled incumbents in an effort to hold down expected Democratic gains in the House and Senate.
articles.abstract: Republicans are trying to save embattled incumbents in an effort to hold down expected Democratic gains in the House and Senate.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Outspent and under siege in a hostile political climate, Congressional Republicans scrambled this weekend to save embattled incumbents in an effort to hold down expected Democratic gains in the House and Senate on Tuesday.

articles.headline: Next President Will Face Test on Detainees
articles.snippet: Dozens of prisoners being held at Guantánamo Bay are regarded by intelligence agencies as serious risks.
articles.abstract: Dozens of prisoners being held at Guantánamo Bay are regarded by intelligence agencies as serious risks.
articles.lead_paragraph: They were called the Dirty 30  bodyguards for Osama bin Laden captured early in the Afghanistan war  and many of them are still being held at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba. Others still at the much-criticized detention camp there include prisoners who the government says were trained in assassination and the use of poisons and disguises.
articles.byline: By William Glaberson and Margot Williams

articles.headline: Debt Linked to Buyouts Tightens the Economic Vise
articles.snippet: Analysts expect an array of private equity firms to face pressure as profits shrink and creditors come knocking.
articles.abstract: Analysts expect an array of private equity firms to face pressure as profits shrink and creditors come knocking.
articles.lead_paragraph: Private equity firms embarked on one of the biggest spending sprees in corporate history for nearly three years, using borrowed money to gobble up huge swaths of industries and some of the biggest names  Neiman Marcus, Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer and Toys “R” Us.
articles.byline: By Andrew Ross Sorkin and Michael J. de la Merced
